Film/video director & music documentarian Don Letts recalls his first time seeing Bob live and meeting him afterwards: 

"I went to Bob Marley’s legendary gig at the Lyceum in ’75 which was released as a live album. It was the closest I have ever got to a religious experience and the single most exciting music moment of my life. The full impact and reality of what we had heard on his records all came together in that show. It was no longer an abstract thing that you could interpret one way or another. Here was the man onstage delivering it live and direct. It gave me the confidence to be myself. Bob Marley brought the politic to the forefront of reggae with a militant Rasta rebel vibe. After the gig I followed Bob Marley in my car back to his hotel in Harrington Gardens, off Gloucester Road. I don’t know what possessed me, I marched into the hotel with all the other Rasta brethren. Everyone was sitting down and I found a little spot in the corner. Bob was holding court in his room and was smoking and ‘reasoning’ with all the Rasta elders. Finally, it was three or four in the morning and Bob had out-reasoned and out-smoked everybody. He looked around the room and saw me with my baby dreads and my pathetic little bag of smoke. I was called to the table and ‘reasoned’ with him until sunrise." Timeline Photos

#TodayInBobsLife: Bob plays one of only a handful of shows as Robert Marley (pre-Wailers) today in 1963!

Story from Derrick Morgan: Leslie Kong sponsored the "Derrick Morgan Farewell Shows". Marley was on both bills, amongst John Holt, Frank Cosmo, Pluggy & Beryl, Roy Panton and others. Derrick made certain that Bob would be featured in the shows, though Derrick noticed that Bob (perhaps nervous) did not have a balance and unison with his performance energies. At the Capri show “when Bob go on stage he was dancin’ more than he was singin’… And ‘im come back to vocal, so mi beg ‘im and se, ‘No youth. When you sing two verses you dance, and then you go back to your other verse.’” At the Montego Bay venue, Bob performed as Derrick had suggested. Nonetheless, “One Cup of Coffee” did not receive the audience responses that either of them expected. In fact, the typically volatile and expressive Jamaican crowd started to boo. “The next song, ‘im just get up and se, ‘Judge not, before you judge yourself.’ When ‘im reach de part de, the audience ray and se, ‘Wait, this boy a bad, ‘im a just mek a sound offa we!’ Same time, yeah man, and a de so ‘im hit. That was the last time I see Bob fe a long while.” Timeline Photos

Birthday Celebrations Question #5 was: Do you have a cool Bob related story to share? Some memory where his music or influence played a role in your life?

And the winner is... Benjamin J. Egan, who shared:

"In the first house I grew up in I remember hanging out in my room I would catch myself staring at a Bob poster thinking, I want to be a revolutionary. Now as a musician, I owe so much to Bob for telling me to, "Wake up and Live..Don't bury your thoughts, put your vision to reality." Bob helped me to deeply understand that action needs to be taken in order to change the world. I hope to change the world through the music I create just as Bob did with an attitude of positive thought and action. Thank you Bob for showing me that I have the power to be the creator of my own destiny. "Every man got a right to decide his own destiny...soon we will find out who is the true revolutionaries"....This is the truth Bob help me to find and live with in all that I do. "

One more question left, and if you liked the "One Love" image, it is available for download free at: http://bobmarley.com/free_stuff_booklets.php Timeline Photos

Birthday Celebrations Question #4 was: What is your favorite Bob Marley album and why?

And the winner is... Arash Fattahi, who wrote:

"I would say 'Survival'. Besides being the first part of his trilogy ideal (Survival, Uprising, Confrontation) it tells some true stories about his life. In this album his militant spirit becomes a deep influence not only in Jamaica but in the African nations. In the song 'Ambush In The Night' he's not afraid of telling the truth about the attempt to murder him, and 'Zimbabwe' becomes an anthem for those nations who seek freedom from their oppressors."

Thanks to everyone who shared their thoughts. New question on Saturday! Timeline Photos

"Revelation reveals the truth..." #Revolution "Revolution" Tuff Gong Studio rehearsal, 1980 — Bob Marley (Videos) Bob Marley & The Wailers rehearse "Revolution" at Tuff Gong Studios in Kingston, Jamaica on May 1, 1980.

#MARLEYFACT: When the Wailers first started selling their music through Coxsone Dodd's Studio One label, they were only making 3 pounds a week.

Because of this, Bob moved to Wilmington, Delaware to live with his mother and make some money. He first worked at the Hotel duPont vacuuming floors, and then for Chrysler as a forklift operator. With the money he made, he returned to Kingston and formed Tuff Gong Records. Timeline Photos
